comment: Very funny guy! Not only is he British, but he makes bread too!! He also really likes Atlanta United, and I told him that he would get along great with my dad. He made biology a fun class. Thank you professor Hudson!

This class was set up in a hybrid way, but it seemed to work out very well. He is a lenient grader for the most part and is very entertaining to listen to during lecture. There are no exams, but instead, long, essay based assignments. Make sure you actually try on these as they are not graded on completion. Overall great guy

The grading format was a study guide, a quiz, and a short answer assignment for each chapter. He is a lenient grader and very understanding when it comes to lateness. He also worked with the students and frequently pushed back due dates if students had a lot going on in other classes. Definitely recommend taking him.

his workload was not so bad there are quizzes, study guides, and assignment exams. The assignment exams do take a few hours to complete, but its better than multiple choice exams. He was a funny guy who really cared about the material and a pretty lenient grader for the most part.

The testing format is difficult. You are given a paper and have to dissect it and have a huge understanding of interpreting and connecting knowledge and answer hand written questions on them. He is a funny guy who loves to tell stories and likes to talk about his cooking. He's a solid choice and nice guy, but its definitely not a super easy A

There were many short answer exams and easy multiple choice quizzes giving you a higher chance of getting a good grade. Also drops a couple of the lowest grade exams. Grading scale was also lowered, allowing you to get an A w/ an 88. Very nice & knowledgeable prof whos easy going. Would take again in a heartbeat if he taught other classes.

great guy. 13 quizzes, drops lowest 2. Exams are kinda difficult- 8 but 2 are dropped. Study guides for each chapter. TON of reading required- definitely get the book. lectures are fun. Counts attendance through polls.

READ THE TEXTBOOK (ESSENTIAL CELL BIOLOGY). If you don't read it, you will struggle through the class. Lectures are only scratch the surface, so read the textbook on a religious basis. Pop quizzes rarely occurs, its mostly announced in previous lectures. Just keep a steady habit of studying, maybe 1/3 of a chapter a day, and you will succeed.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Test heavy--Clear grading criteria

comment: Hudson is a great professor. He gives about 16 quizzes with only 10 counting. Expect one at least once a week. The textbook actually helps. Draw the pathways when he does in class. Need a clicker for participation. 3 exams (mc, t/f and why, and free response) and one final. Final replaces lowest exam grade. If you study a little more you can get A
rating_tags: Participation matters--Skip class? You won't pass.--Beware of pop quizzes

comment: Dr. Hudson is a great professor. He posts a lot on D2L, has a british accent, gives practice problems, final replaces lowest test grade, a lot of quizzes but drops a bunch. His one downfall is announcing tests/quizzes not very far in advance. Record his lectures! Funny guy with very hard tests. A LOT of time out of class teaching yourself.
rating_tags: Participation matters--Skip class? You won't pass.--Test heavy

comment: 88 is an A in this class, 78 is a B. He's really nice and available during office hours. The tests are really hard: multiple choice, true/false and why, essay/short answer questions. We had clicker quizzes almost every class or a take home quiz. Easy to make a B but you have to work really hard for an A.

Second class with Dr. Hudson and I'd take another. Cell bio is hard but he tries to do whatever necessary to ensure success. This is upper level so you must go to class TAKE NOTES and read the book. Exams are difficult but if you prep the right way you'll be fine. Ask questions Do the quizzes Answer iClicker questions. I got an A with diligent work
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--BEWARE OF POP QUIZZES--Tests are tough

comment: This class is unnecessarily difficult. The more it progresses, the worse  it gets. Hudson can be cool but if you don't understand something he can be quite rude about explaining it. And heads up, His tests are REALLY hard. He's nice to talk to, but the labs are really hard

Smart man & topics in this class are his specialty.  Material is interesting but difficult. He tells funny stories and comparisons in lecture. Be prepared to devote a ton of time outside of class  studying. He cares about your success and is happy to schedule time outside of class to go over material if you need extra help.
rating_tags: BEWARE OF POP QUIZZES--ACCESSIBLE OUTSIDE CLASS--LECTURE HEAVY

comment: I took genetics lab with Dr. Hudson. It started out okay but it got harder and harder and he got less and less helpful. He does want his students to succeed and he actually altered his whole syllabus to save our skins, but the class was unnecessarily hard and had many disconnects from lecture. He's nice and funny but you seriously have to work.

Cell biology was very hard, but Dr. Hudson  gives you the tools to succeed. The textbook is 100% necessary as it really helps amplify the lecture understanding. While the tests are hard there's never any surprises. As long as you come to class and study you will do well
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Skip class? You won't pass.--LECTURE HEAVY

comment: The lab itself was pretty easy but you are graded on basically just five quizzes so you really need to know your stuff.

LOVE HIM. TAKE HIM! He is so smart and cell bio is a hard subject to grasp but he is 100% there to help. His tests are difficult: multi choice, T/F, and essay questions. Quizzes during class sometimes and always provides review questions for tests. Adds funny stories during lecture and his accent is great. READ THE BOOK. Honestly. Life saver!

Dr. Hudson is beyond smart. This class is tough and it requires a lot of work outside of class. However, Hudson is a great professor. He always includes funny stories. Take him if you can but be prepared to work hard.

He may not have the warmest smile or the biggest heart, but Dr. Hudson is a genius of I have ever met one. He can be a bit harsh and inadvertently rude, but he does a fantastic job at conveying his extensive and borderline obsessive knowledge of genetics to the students.

Hes a great professor who knows his stuff and if you don't understand something just ask him and he'll help you out. This class is interesting but it is hard and if you want an A you'll have to work for it. Study the power points and his notes and do NOT cram for his tests or you will fail. His lab is also pretty easy

Dr. Hudson is absolutely brilliant. He understands the material inside and out and teaches genetics thoroughly. It is not an easy course but he does everything in his power to make sure you understand the material. So yes, you have to work for your grade and, no, it is not an easy A. Welcome to college.

Ok, problem is he's teaches you like you have a PhD already, hes very very intelligent, but when your seeing geneics for the first time its difficult. He is way to used to teaching medical micro and such. Nice guy, sometimes off topic. Go for Davis or Xaugie (said How-gee). I was in every class and lab, Im usually an A student, first D ever.

Great professor. Granted this class isn't an easy A, but all of the information is clearly given in the powerpoints. There are no surprises on the tests, he just might ask very specific questions that you didn't think to study. The book isn't necessary and if you have any questions he is extremely helpful and easy to talk to. A starts at 86 not 90.

Took him Spring "11 and he doesn't teach genetics well. Granted its a tough topic, but he does it no justice. When you talk to him he is very helpful, but lectures powerpoint slides he reads and tests are nothing like the quizzes or notes. I have no clue where he gets those questions from. The 2nd half of the class is harder than the first.
Amazing Professor that exudes brilliance. If you want to become a better scientist...his class is a must!!

It almost seems like he expects everyone to be as smart as he is, and doesn't do much teaching in class except going over powerpoints of information straight out of the book. On tests be expected to know material that wasn't even covered in class. Read the book, it's your only hope to pass the class.

He talks in non-linear circles, he's scatterbrained. Ask a good question, and as an answer, he'll say, "We'll come back to it", and we never do. He gives you practice problems, and says, "I'll post the answers", and never does. The only successful thing he does in class is trick you on exams. Take Chen for the win.

Not the best teacher in the world, but he's reasonable, helpful, passionate and funny. If you find you're having issues with the material, talk to him during office hours. He expects a lot from his students, but he wants them to do well. I strongly recommend him (especially over Chen!)
I found the classes interesting and fresh and I had no problems understanding the information.  Professor Hudson has a great sense of humour, too.  (And he's English!  What's not to like?) )

Worst college professor I've ever had. Lectures are carbon copies of diagrams from text book. Impatient with students. Will make simple concepts far more complicated. Do not waste your time listening to his lectures - it's not helpful! Read the text book, it will explain the concepts much better. Less than 20% of students pass his exams. No curve.
